verses.text: In those days, Mattathias son of John, son of Simeon, a priest of the family of Joarib, left Jerusalem and dwelled in Modein.
verses.comment: Mattathias, a priestly leader, leaves Jerusalem at a time of crisis, introducing the Hasmonean family central to the following narrative.

verses.text: He had five sons: John, called Gaddi;
verses.comment: The sons of Mattathias play key roles in the revolt. Their names are significant for tracing the continuation of Israel's leadership.

verses.text: Simon, called Thassi;
verses.comment: Simon will later become leader of the Jewish people.

verses.text: Judas, called Maccabeus;
verses.comment: Judas is the most renowned, leading the military defense and restoration of Israel’s worship.

verses.text: Eleazar, called Avaran; and Jonathan, called Apphus.
verses.comment: The sons' alternate names are reported according to Jewish custom. Their involvement displays fraternal leadership.

verses.text: When he saw the blasphemies committed in Judah and Jerusalem,
verses.comment: Mattathias is moved by seeing the desecration of worship, recalling the zeal of prophets against idolatry.

verses.text: he said, 'Woe is me! Why was I born to see the destruction of my people and the devastation of the holy city, and to live there when it was given into the hands of the enemy, the sanctuary into the hands of foreigners?
verses.comment: Mattathias laments much like the psalmist, voicing deep sorrow over the fall of Jerusalem—a spiritual and national tragedy.

verses.text: Her temple has become like a man without glory.
verses.comment: The loss of temple glory signifies the interruption of sacred worship—a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: Her glorious vessels have been carried off as plunder, her infants have been killed in the streets, her young men have fallen by the sword of the enemy.
verses.comment: The description parallels the lamentations over Jerusalem’s fall. The imagery reinforces the need for restoration.

verses.text: 'What nation has not taken a share from her kingdom and seized her goods?
verses.comment: A rhetorical question, emphasizing the universal extent of Israel’s suffering.

verses.text: All her adornment has been removed. Instead of freedom, she has become a slave.
verses.comment: The spiritual and political subjugation of God’s people becomes a call for deliverance.

verses.text: See, our holy place, our beauty, and our glory have been laid waste. The Gentiles have defiled them.
verses.comment: Desolation of sacred places often precedes historic revivals of worship, showing God’s desire for restoration.

verses.text: Why should we continue to live?'
verses.comment: A biblical moment of existential despair, similar to Job and the psalmist, leading to deeper faith and reliance on God.

verses.text: Then Mattathias and his sons tore their clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourned deeply.
verses.comment: Tearing garments and sackcloth signal profound grief—custom deeply rooted in Jewish tradition.

verses.text: The king's officers, who were enforcing apostasy, came to Modein to make the people sacrifice.
verses.comment: Apostasy is forced by political authorities, challenging faithfulness to God’s covenant.

verses.text: Many from Israel came to them, and Mattathias and his sons were assembled.
verses.comment: The division among the people—some compromising, some resisting—anticipates Christ’s call to stand firm in faith.

verses.text: Then the king’s officers addressed Mattathias, saying, 'You are a leader, noble and respected in this city, supported by sons and brothers.
verses.comment: Between the lines, Mattathias’s influence hints at the spiritual responsibility of elders within the community.

verses.text: So come forward first and carry out the command of the king, as all the nations have done, and the people of Judah and those who remain in Jerusalem. Then you and your sons will be numbered among the king’s friends, and you and your sons will be honored with silver and gold and many gifts.'
verses.comment: The authorities tempt Mattathias with honor and material reward in exchange for compliance—a recurring ethical challenge throughout the bible.

verses.text: But Mattathias replied in a loud voice, 'Even if all the nations under the king’s rule obey him and abandon the religion of their fathers, and choose to follow his laws,
verses.comment: Mattathias’s response echoes Daniel and other faithful ones who resist pagan pressures in exile.

verses.text: my sons and I will continue to live by the covenant of our fathers.
verses.comment: Covenant loyalty is a foundational biblical principle, tracing back to Abraham’s promises.

verses.text: God forbid that we should forsake the law and the commandments!
verses.comment: Upholding divine law is presented as a sacred duty, prefiguring Christian fidelity to the Gospel.

verses.text: We will not obey the king’s decree nor depart from our religion in the slightest degree.'
verses.comment: Faithfulness under trial reoccurs in the stories of the prophets and martyrs.

verses.text: As he finished speaking, a Jew came forward in the sight of all to offer sacrifice on the altar in Modein according to the king’s order.
verses.comment: The passage highlights the tragic division among God’s people, and the constant temptation towards compromise is a theme restated by New Testament writers.

verses.text: When Mattathias saw this, he was filled with zeal, and his heart was stirred, and he acted according to righteous anger. He ran and killed him upon the altar.
verses.comment: Mattathias’s action recalls Phinehas’s zealous defense of the faith. The idea of righteous zeal is later taken up by Jesus cleansing the temple (John 2:17).

verses.text: At that time, he also killed the king’s officer who was forcing people to sacrifice, and he tore down the altar.
verses.comment: Destroying the pagan altar echoes Gideon’s destruction of Baal’s altar. The pattern of reform through direct action is consistent in the Old Testament.

verses.text: Thus he showed his zeal for the law, as Phinehas did with Zimri son of Salu.
verses.comment: The comparison to Phinehas establishes Mattathias as a model of zealous devotion.

verses.text: Then Mattathias cried out loudly in the city, saying, 'Let everyone who is zealous for the Law and supports the covenant, follow me!'
verses.comment: The call to loyal followers and supporters is reminiscent of Jesus’s command to “take up your cross and follow Me.”

verses.text: So he and his sons fled into the mountains, leaving all they had in the city.
verses.comment: Abandoning possessions for the sake of faith prepares one for spiritual renewal—a theme echoed by Christ’s disciples.

verses.text: Many who sought justice and righteousness went down to the wilderness to live there,
verses.comment: Withdrawal into the wilderness prefigures John the Baptist, Jesus, and the early Christian hermits who sought purity and renewal in solitude.

verses.text: along with their sons, wives, and livestock, suffering greatly from the evils.
verses.comment: Their willingness to endure deprivation echoes the faith of the patriarchs.

verses.text: When it was reported to the king's officers and the troops in Jerusalem, in the city of David, that those who rejected the king’s command had fled into hiding places in the wilderness,
verses.comment: The pressure on religious minorities results in flight, reminiscent of many periods of persecution in history.

verses.text: they pursued them many and overtook them, and encamped against them to prepare for battle against them on the Sabbath day.
verses.comment: The choice of the Sabbath—day of rest and worship—underscores the deeper battle for the soul of Israel.

verses.text: They said to them, 'Enough! Come out and do as the king commands, and you will live.'
verses.comment: The appeal for compliance rather than destruction is rejected by those who hold God’s commands above earthly decrees.

verses.text: But they answered, 'We will not come out nor do as the king commands, nor profane the Sabbath.'
verses.comment: Sabbath keeping under persecution shows the cost of true worship and reminds believers to honor sacred rituals even in adversity.

verses.text: The enemy quickly attacked them.
verses.comment: Martyrdom as a testimony to faith becomes a path for sanctification—a key biblical reality.

verses.text: They did not respond, or throw stones, or block up the hiding places.
verses.comment: Passive resistance is seen here as a willingness to suffer for God’s law—recalling later Christian martyrs.

verses.text: So they died, along with their wives, children, and herds, about a thousand people.
verses.comment: Martyrdom for faith foreshadows the sacrificial witness of Christians through history, and the promise of resurrection for those who die in hope.

verses.text: When Mattathias and his friends learned of this, they mourned deeply for them.
verses.comment: Communal mourning for martyrs builds spiritual solidarity within the faithful.

verses.text: They said to one another, 'If we all do as our brethren have done and refuse to fight on the Sabbath and are killed, then quickly we will be wiped out from the earth.'
verses.comment: A dilemma arises about the interpretation of Sabbath law versus survival, similar to questions raised in the Gospels about lawful deeds on the Sabbath.

verses.text: So then, they determined, 'If anyone attacks us on the Sabbath, we will fight to protect ourselves, so that we may not all die like our brothers in the hiding places.'
verses.comment: Sacred law is interpreted with wisdom: preservation of life takes precedence—echoing Jesus’s teaching (Matt 12:7).

verses.text: So the group agreed on this, and from that day on they gave themselves to defend themselves on the Sabbath whenever it was necessary.
verses.comment: Mercy and necessity shape interpretation of law, showing its fulfillment in charity and love.

verses.text: A group of Hasideans joined them, mighty warriors of Israel, all devoted to the Law.
verses.comment: Hasideans—righteous ones—formed early dedicated communities, paralleling the later growth of religious orders seeking purity.

verses.text: All those who were fleeing from the evil joined them and strengthened them.
verses.comment: Spiritual unity in adversity draws together faithful from diverse backgrounds—anticipating the gathering of the one fold (cf. John 10:16).

verses.text: They formed a strong force, struck down sinners in their anger, and the lawless fled in fear.
verses.comment: A just order is established, showing both discipline and mercy that foreshadows the coming kingdom.

verses.text: Mattathias and his friends traveled around, tearing down the pagan altars;
verses.comment: Religious reform involves the removal of idolatrous practices—recalling cycles throughout Israel’s history.

verses.text: They forcibly circumcised all the uncircumcised children they found within the territory of Israel.
verses.comment: Restoration of covenant signs parallels spiritual rebirth and initiation, anticipating later sacramental practice for entering into God’s people.

verses.text: They acted zealously for the law, and every lawless person found was dealt with.
verses.comment: Upholding the law with zeal has been interpreted as both literal and spiritual reform, anticipating ongoing sanctification.

verses.text: Thus they rescued the law out of the hands of the Gentiles and kings, and did not allow the sinner to triumph.
verses.comment: Restoration of the law and worship sets a precedent for protecting the faith in all generations.

verses.text: Now, when the days of Mattathias drew near for him to die, he said to his sons,
verses.comment: The father’s blessing at death recalls Jacob and Moses passing the faith on to the next generation.

verses.text: 'Now, my children, be zealous for the Law and give your lives for the covenant of our fathers.
verses.comment: Call for zeal is echoed in Christ’s call to take up one's cross, bringing forward the principle of sacrificial fidelity.

verses.text: Remember the deeds of the fathers, what they did in generation after generation, and you will receive great honor and an everlasting name.
verses.comment: Perseverance brings honor and lasting legacy—sustaining the faithful throughout history.

verses.text: Was not Abraham found faithful when tested, and it was counted to him as righteousness?
verses.comment: Echoes the doctrine of justification by faith—Abraham’s witness later cited by Paul.

verses.text: Joseph in the time of his distress kept the commandment and became ruler of Egypt.
verses.comment: Faithfulness through trials brings vindication—Joseph’s story prefigures Christ as the suffering servant.

verses.text: Phinehas our father, because of his zeal, received the covenant of everlasting priesthood.
verses.comment: Priestly succession in zeal is noted—covenant priesthood recalls God’s promise and care for faithful leaders.

verses.text: Joshua, for carrying out the word, became judge over Israel.
verses.comment: Joshua typifies faithful fulfillment, and his leadership points to the importance of obedience.

verses.text: Caleb, for his witness before the gathering, received an inheritance in the land.
verses.comment: Caleb’s fidelity is an encouragement toward perseverance—a spiritual inheritance for the faithful.

verses.text: David, for being merciful, inherited the throne of the kingdom forever.
verses.comment: David’s everlasting kingdom is a messianic promise, ultimately fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Elijah, because of his zeal for the Law, was taken up into heaven.
verses.comment: Elijah’s translation to heaven prefigures hope of resurrection and life beyond death.

verses.text: Hananiah, Azariah, and Mishael believed, and were saved from the fire.
verses.comment: Faithfulness under trial leads to miraculous rescue, foreshadowing spiritual deliverance for all believers.

verses.text: Daniel, for his innocence, was delivered from the mouth of lions.
verses.comment: Daniel typifies righteous suffering and trust in God’s salvation—a type for Christ himself.

verses.text: Know therefore, that in each generation those who put their trust in God will not be lacking.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness to those who trust Him is a major biblical theme, and assurance of continuing grace and presence.

verses.text: Do not fear the threats of sinners, but remember that their glory will turn to ashes and their roar will vanish.
verses.comment: Assurance of justice underpins the hope of the righteous against worldly intimidation.

verses.text: Today they are exalted, but tomorrow they are gone; for they return to dust and their plans perish.
verses.comment: Temporal power is fleeting. True glory is found in faith and obedience to God.

verses.text: My children, be courageous and strong in the Law, for by it you will be honored.
verses.comment: Courage in faith is necessary—divine law the foundation for lasting honor and true strength.

verses.text: Behold, your brother Simeon I know is wise in counsel. Listen to him always; he shall be your father.
verses.comment: Leadership and succession are handed on through the family, with the concept of spiritual fatherhood recognized.

verses.text: Judas, who is strong and brave from his youth, shall be your commander, and wage war against the nations.
verses.comment: Spiritual and military leadership are distinguished—Judas is chosen for his valor.

verses.text: Gather everyone who loves the Law, and take revenge on your enemies. Repay them according to the command of the Law.
verses.comment: The demand for justice is tempered with mercy, echoing the psalmist’s hope for vindication and God’s ultimate justice.

verses.text: Repay the Gentiles, and keep the commandments of the Law.
verses.comment: Obedience to God, rather than vengeance, is emphasized as the true mark of the faithful.

verses.text: So he blessed them, he was gathered to his fathers.
verses.comment: Mattathias’s blessing and passing away recalls patriarchal traditions—pointing beyond earthly life toward resurrection hope in Christ.

verses.text: He died in the one hundred and forty-sixth year and was buried in his ancestral tomb at Modein, and all Israel mourned deeply for him.
verses.comment: The communal mourning marks Mattathias as a major figure in Israel’s history, with his legacy continued in his sons and in enduring faithfulness.
